The modern Hong Kong diaspora was defined by a fear of Beijing. In the years before it was handed back to China from Britain in 1997, an estimated 800,000 people left for the United Kingdom, Canada, Australia, the United States, and elsewhere, with emigration rising sharply after the 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre.
